title: 109_hr1912
content: The Act titled "Emergency Immigration Workload Reduction and Homeland Security Enhancement Act of 2005" is also known as the Short Title. It includes a Table of Contents outlining the sections of the Act. The Act titled "Emergency Immigration Workload Reduction and Homeland Security Enhancement Act of 2005" includes sections on temporary suspension of various visa programs, restriction of nonimmigrant visas for certain nationals, waivers of temporary suspensions, and termination of temporary suspensions. It also addresses funding for detention and removal assistance provided by State and local law enforcement agencies. SEC. 2. SEVERABILITY. If any provision of this Act is held unconstitutional, the rest of the Act remains unaffected. SEC. 3. FINDINGS. The Congress emphasizes the importance of the effective establishment and organization of the Directorate of Border and Transportation Security to carry out immigration enforcement responsibilities. Certain immigration programs may need to be temporarily suspended to ensure national security interests are not compromised until the Secretary of Homeland Security can make required certifications to Congress. The Congress emphasizes the importance of establishing the Directorate of Border and Transportation Security for immigration enforcement. Certifications to Congress will demonstrate the effective transfer of immigration enforcement functions to the new Directorate. SEC. 4 suspends the Visa Waiver Program for aliens entering the US. SEC. 5 suspends the adjustment of status for aliens seeking permanent residence. SEC. 6 suspends renewals of Temporary Protected Status. SEC. 6 suspends renewals of Temporary Protected Status. SEC. 7 suspends certain immigrant visa programs. The allocation of family-sponsored immigrant visas for siblings and children of US citizens, as well as unmarried sons and daughters of permanent resident aliens, is suspended under the Immigration and Nationality Act. The allocation of immigrant visas for certain family-sponsored and diversity immigrants is suspended under the Immigration and Nationality Act. The suspension of immigrant visa allocations under section 203(c) of the Immigration and Nationality Act includes the suspension of acceptance for filing of petitions for classification under section 204 for affected immigrant visa categories. SEC. 8. RESTRICTION OF NONIMMIGRANT VISAS FOR NATIONALS OF COUNTRIES DENYING OR DELAYING ACCEPTANCE OF ALIENS. The Secretary of Homeland Security will create a public listing of aliens with final removal orders but no significant likelihood of being removed due to countries refusing or unreasonably delaying acceptance. If 24 or more citizens of a foreign state are on this list, that state will be considered as denying or unreasonably delaying acceptance of these aliens. The Secretary of Homeland Security will notify the Secretary of State if a foreign state denies or unreasonably delays accepting aliens with final removal orders. Consular officers in that state will stop issuing nonimmigrant visas to its citizens. Subsection (a) will sunset according to section 10. The Secretary of Homeland Security has the authority to waive certain sections on a case-by-case basis or for designated classes of applicants, with the concurrence of the Secretary of State. The waiver authority can be delegated to the Secretary of State for certain applicants. Temporary suspensions will be terminated according to section 10. Sections 4 through 9 will expire one week after the Secretary of Homeland Security certifies to Congress that the entry and exit data system and visa technology requirements are fully operational at all ports of entry. The Department of Homeland Security must have the operational capability to detain and remove certain aliens, adequate federal funds must be available for verified claims, and the data system for alien registration must be fully compliant and operational. The data system for alien registration must be fully compliant with integration and interoperability standards, ensuring timely entry of registrations and notices of address changes. The Department of Homeland Security must ensure timely entry of change of address notices within 5 working days. A random audit program for immigration status changes must be implemented, with fraud incidence not exceeding 3%. The foreign student monitoring system must comply with the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Act. The Department of Homeland Security must ensure timely entry of change of address notices within 5 working days. A random audit program for immigration status changes must be implemented, with fraud incidence not exceeding 3%. Section 641 of the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act is fully operational, ensuring that educational institutions do not admit aliens in violation of the law. The number of aliens removed from the United States must be at least 25% higher than the previous year for 4 consecutive months before certification. All reports, plans, and operational transfers must be in compliance. The Department of Homeland Security has successfully completed all required reports, plans, and operational transfers under the Homeland Security Act of 2002. The backlog of immigration benefit applications has been eliminated, and the necessary annual report has been submitted to Congress. Process changes outlined in the American Competitiveness in the Twenty-first Century Act have been implemented. The American Competitiveness in the Twenty-first Century Act of 2000 has been implemented and is operational. SEC. 11. SUSPENSION OF NONIMMIGRANT VISAS. The Secretary of State's authority to issue nonimmigrant visas and the Secretary of Homeland Security's authority to admit nonimmigrant aliens into the United States are suspended. This includes the suspension of accepting applications for nonimmigrant visas and admission as a nonimmigrant. The Secretary of Homeland Security may waive these suspensions under certain conditions. Personal interviews are required for aliens seeking admission to the United States under section 217 of the Immigration and Nationality Act. The Secretary, along with the Secretary of State, ensures that each alien entering on a nonimmigrant visa has undergone a personal interview with a consular officer. Additionally, any waiver granted to aliens barred from receiving nonimmigrant visas will be overridden by the bar during the waiver period. SEC. 12. TEMPORARY FUNDING FOR DETENTION AND REMOVAL ASSISTANCE BY STATE AND LOCAL LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCIES. The Secretary of Homeland Security will reimburse law enforcement agencies for emergency medical care, housing, and transportation of detained aliens if they are found removable or have permanently left the US, excluding transportation costs. Reimbursement for all costs except transportation is based on a per diem rate set by the Secretary, with the first day of detention not later than the certification date in section 9. The Act will take effect in each local time zone on the first Sunday occurring two weeks after its enactment.
